isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - HEHR POWER SYSTEMS/POWERLINE ALTERNATORS USED ON EMERGENCY VEHICLES - TESTING AND ANALYSIS OF CHARGING SYSTEM

svcsubsec.title: TESTING AND ANALYSIS OF CHARGING SYSTEM

svcsubsecinfo.para:
You will need a clamp-on ammeter, a tape measure, a tachometer (either hand held or in the dashboard), and the power curve for the alternator on the vehicle. Copies of the Power curves
are provided at the end of this manual and are kept current in the Powerline data book. It is a good idea to record all data.

step1.para: Test the vehicle as you find it. Measure the voltage directly across each battery and check to see if there is any current flowing out of it (parasitic load). Then check all load switches/loads to make sure they are off. Disconnect battery cables, wait 30 seconds and estimate the battery's state of charge by measuring open circuit voltage. 12.6 to 12.8 volts is 100% charged, 12.3 to 12.6 is 75% charged, 12.1 to 12.3 is 50% and 11.8 to 12.3 is 25% charged. If the battery is below 12.3 VDC, charge it before doing the test below.
Document the vehicle's equipment and connections.

step2.para: Record the alternator model#, S/N, and date code.

Observe the 3 #10 bolts on the brush housing (rear face of alternator). A strap between the POSITIVE POST and FIELD CURRENT TERMINAL and a strap between the FIELD CURRENT TERMINAL and the VOLTAGE SENSE terminal, gives a local or alternator sense. A wire directly to the battery from the FIELD CURRENT TERMINAL (no strap from POSITIVE POST to FIELD CURRENT) gives a remote or battery sense. Leave the VOLTAGE SENSE to FIELD CURRENT TERMINAL strap in place. This mode gives the best system performance.

Measure the O.D. of the engine pulley and the alternator pulley (pulley ratio = O.D. of engine pulley/O.D. of alternator pulley). If the alternator pulley is larger than 2.5 inches, you are probably not getting optimum output at idle speeds.
What size is the POS battery cable from the alternator to the battery? Is there a NEG. cable from the alternator to the battery, or is a chassis ground being used to carry large currents?
Does the vehicle have a fast idle device? Is it manual or automatically engaged with loads? What engine speed does it produce?
Does the vehicle have a load management system? Is it automatic?

step1.para: For each of the conditions below, measure the voltage directly across the terminals and the current flowing in or out of the alternator and each battery.

step2.para: Record pulley ratio and the engine RPM during natural engine idle. Apply the loads that would be used either upon arrival or during clean-up at an emergency scene. List the loads and measure the voltage and currents used by each. Pay close attention to the battery current. Is it flowing in (charge) or out (discharge)? If there are multiple wires to a battery, make the current measurement on each one and add up the total.

Engage the fast idle device, if equipped. Measure and record the engine RPM. Apply the loads which would normally be used in a worst case (full ON) scenario at the scene. List them and make voltage and current readings, both initially and after 15 minutes. Pay close attention to the battery current polarity. Is it flowing in (charge) or out (discharge)? Expect the alternator output to drop about 20 amps during the 15 minute test (due to heating effects).

Is the alternator putting out the current it should? Terminal voltage should be above 13.6 volts and the current should be either equal to the demand load or at least that shown on the power curve for the operating rotor speed (Alt. speed = Eng. RPM X pulley ratio).
If the battery is discharging in either idle mode, the system will eventually end up with dead batteries. You will have to attempt to optimize the existing system or upgrade the alternator.
